description.narrative:
The loss of investor confidence, caused initially by the August 2008 conflict and then by the international financial crisis have caused a sharp slowdown in capital inflows (both foreign direct investment and private lending) to Georgia. The inflows may not recover to the pre-crises levels until 2010. These exogenous shocks are being amplified by a slowdown in Georgia's export markets and a reduction in incoming remittances. All major components of aggregate demand in the economy have contracted and the macroeconomic outlook for Georgia has been revised downwards, and remains very uncertain at this stage. Before the August conflict, real gross domestic product (GDP) was forecast to grow at 11-12% in 2008. The actual GDP growth was 2%, with the forecast for 2009 at 1%. Economic activity has slowed considerably, profit margins have sharply decreased, and layoffs have risen. The social consequences of these developments could be very severe.
The Government and the monetary and financial sector authorities in Georgia have worked closely to address these challenges. When the Georgian lari came under pressure in August 2008, and again in October and November, the National Bank of Georgia (NBG) intervened to support the currency. To shore up reserves depleted in defense of the lari and to bolster lari depositor confidence, the Government and the NBG entered into a $750 million Stand-By Arrangement (SBA) with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). By helping to rebuild the official foreign exchange reserves and to restore confidence in the lari, the SBA framework supports the Government's macroeconomic policy objectives of accelerating recovery through fiscal stimulus, allowing exchange rate flexibility, and safeguarding banking system stability.
A significant macroeconomic stimulus is required to counter these adverse shocks. However, the very high and increasing use of the US dollar in the economy constrains what fiscal or monetary policy can do. Such constraints can only be relaxed by: (i) recourse to external and long-term loans from development partners to finance core public expenditures and augment foreign exchange reserves, and (ii) maintenance of some exchange rate stability, to avoid sharp fluctuations in the value of the lari. In parallel, the banking system needs to remain stable for these measures to be effective.
The joint needs assessment (JNA) by several development partners in September 2008 remains the most appropriate framework for dealing with the crisis, both in terms of assessing the need for, and designing, budget support and infrastructure and social sector assistance. The JNA identifies a need for intervention and development partner assistance in three major areas: (i) to help the Government ensure that critical economic and social needs are met and confidence is maintained, with quick-disbursing budget support to back-stop countercyclical fiscal measures of rapid effect; (ii) to resettle internally displaced persons and address the post-conflict needs of affected populations; and (iii) to support critical new investments. The JNA notes that high-value and high-yield investments are key to maximizing recovery prospects and that such investments will also have lasting positive effects on the economy's productive capacity.
The JNA estimated the overall resource requirements at $3.7 billion over a 3-year period. Actions were prioritized in three stages: stage 1 (6 months, September 2008-March 2009); stage 2 (12 months, April 2009-March 2010); and stage 3 (12-18 months, March 2010-September 2011). The relevance of the JNA has been reinforced by the severity of the impact of the crisis on Georgia and the continuing uncertainty of capital flows.
The proposed Program is a follow-up to the EAPCR. The macroeconomic policy framework anchor is provided for in the SBA between Georgia and the IMF. Like the earlier program, it is anchored on the JNA. It will continue ADB support for the Government to help it meet critical public expenditures and cushion the adverse revenue shocks that will probably persist throughout 2009. The Program will complement two planned ADB infrastructure projects (the Municipal and Urban Infrastructure Development Project and the Ajara Bypass Roads Project). The World Bank plans to provide $85 million in budget support through its Development Policy Operation. The European Union is also expected to provide budgetary assistance in the near future. The Program will support the following outputs.
Output 1. Incremental expenditure needs arising from the worse-than-expected economic conditions in 2009 are met without complete drawn down of cash balances at NBG.
Output 2. The delivery of the core Government expenditure program for 2009 in accordance with the approved budget, irrespective of subsequent revisions that take into account shortfalls in revenue.

title.narrative: Reports and Recommendations of the President
